<h3 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-price-management" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#price-management"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Price management</h3>
<p dir="auto">As an Advertiser, I want changes in my products price changes to be reflected in near real time in my ads.</p>
<p dir="auto">I.e. I don't want to display an incorrect price in an ad.</p>
<h3 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-products-promotion-management" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#products-promotion-management"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Products promotion management</h3>
<p dir="auto">As an Advertiser, I want to be able to push forward a set of product in my ads: i.e. during a certain period of time increase the frequency of display for these products.</p>
<p dir="auto">This use case is common in sales period. Note that sales period can have very precise start and stop dates.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-creatives" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#creatives"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Creatives</h2>
<p dir="auto">Advertisers want to optimize the look and feel of their ads to the audience and to the environment. This helps to drive more performance and improve their overall brand recognition.</p>
<p dir="auto">This can be done programmatically using historical aggregated and/or personal user data, and contextual information.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-coupon-management" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#coupon-management"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Coupon Management</h2>
<p dir="auto">As an Advertiser I want to be able to add coupons, or any form of targeted discounts to my creatives on specific period of times, potentially for specific products.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-product-recommendation" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#product-recommendation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Product Recommendation</h2>
<p dir="auto">Large e-Commerce websites may have product catalogs with millions of items. They have an interesting use-case. When running ads to promote items from their vast catalogs, which product should they show?
Today, much of this is mainly powered by data about which items were previously browsed and by visitor's interactions with e-Commerce websites. Product definition is much greater because e-Commerce consists of diverse business models. ( e.g. For travel e-Commerce or employment portals product catalog consists of offers.)</p>
<p dir="auto">Typical sources of recommendation models would be :</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Historical Products (compared to historical products browsed): abandoned cart, etc.</li>
<li>Similar products (compared to historical products browsed)</li>
<li>Complementary Products (compared to historical products browsed)</li>
<li>...</li>
</ul>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-ml-applications" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#ml-applications"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>ML Applications</h1>
<p dir="auto">There are many advertising use-cases which rely on Machine Learning today. Common themes involve selecting from a vast number of options, and making efficient use of historical data. Following are several of the key uses of Machine Learning in advertising today:</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-ad-campaign-selection" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#ad-campaign-selection"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Ad-campaign selection</h2>
<p dir="auto">Ad-campaign selection is a very important task. e.g. There are many advertising campaigns to choose from. These might be promoting different types of conversion events (e.g. some are promoting mobile app installs, some are promoting purchases on websites, some are just optimized to generate link-clicks, some are optimized to generate video-views).</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-ad-component-selection" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#ad-component-selection"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Ad-component selection</h2>
<p dir="auto">Ads are composed of multiple components (e.g. the title, description, image, video, etc.). Some ads are promoting particular products/offers. Once an ad-campaign is selected, ML is used to select which components to use in each particular ad impression. (e.g. which products to highlights, which title text to use, which image to use). These options are constrained by what the advertiser has provided as options for their ad-campaign and lastly optimized to maximize probability of reaching Advertiser's desired goal.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-bidding-logic" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#bidding-logic"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Bidding logic</h2>
<p dir="auto">Machine Learning is used to estimate the efficacy of ad placements. Across an ad network, there might be millions of placements, across hundreds of thousands of publisher websites, each with different properties (like size and location on the page). How much return on investment will each placement drive for each advertiser? Machine learning is used to make such estimates.</p>
<p dir="auto">The lower the accuracy of the prediction in bidding logic, the fewer business outcomes will be generated for the same budget. This in turn leads to lower publisher revenue.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-formatting-customization" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#formatting-customization"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Formatting customization</h2>
<p dir="auto">Once the ad-campaign and components are selected, choices remain about how exactly to render that set of components (e.g. click button on the right or the left. Which animation style to choose and maximize probability of click?).</p>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-training-ml-models" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#training-ml-models"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Training ML Models</h1>
<p dir="auto">Machine learning models must be trained with sample data. They must be provided with both “positive” and “negative” training samples. There are a few key types of ML models to consider</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-click-through-rate-ctr-model-pclick--impression" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#click-through-rate-ctr-model-pclick--impression"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Click Through Rate (CTR) Model: P(click | impression)</h2>
<p dir="auto">The “CTR model” predicts the likelihood of a click given an impression. This can be done entirely with first party data. The publisher should be aware of which ads received were clicked, and which ads were not. These provide “positive” and “negative” training samples which can be used to train a machine learning model that predicts how likely someone is to click on an ad if it is shown to them.</p>
<p dir="auto">An ad server which just utilizes a “CTR Model” will be able to optimize for the cheapest clicks. It will maximize the number of clicks for a given budget.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-conversion-rate-cvr-model-pconversion--click" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#conversion-rate-cvr-model-pconversion--click"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Conversion Rate (CVR) Model: P(conversion | click)</h2>
<p dir="auto">Just optimizing for clicks may not lead to desirable results. Clicks are only a weak proxy for business value. Some clicks will result in conversions and business value generation, but others will not. Some clicks might be accidental, or could even be fraudulent. Advertisers do not want to pay for cheap clicks than seldom result in conversions, they want ads that actually create business value.</p>
<p dir="auto">For this reason, another important use-case is to train “CVR Models”, that predict the likelihood of a conversion given a click. Training such a machine learning model will require “positive” and “negative” training samples as well. “Positive” samples are clicks which eventually resulted in a conversion. “Negative” samples are clicks which did not result in a conversion.</p>
<p dir="auto">Bayesian probability tells us that we can compute the probability of a conversion given an impression by just multiplying these two predictions:</p>
<p dir="auto">P(conversion | impression) = P(conversion | click) * P(click | impression)</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-post-view-attribution-pconversion--impression" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#post-view-attribution-pconversion--impression"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Post-view attribution: P(conversion | impression)</h2>
<p dir="auto">Post-view attribution is still widely used across the industry, particularly for branding campaigns.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-pdisplay--request" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#pdisplay--request"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>P(Display | Request)</h2>
<p dir="auto">In this competitive environment, particularly in a first-price auctions world, advertisers may want to infer the probability of winning the auction (getting the display) depending on their bid.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-return-on-ad-spend-roas-optimization" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#return-on-ad-spend-roas-optimization"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Return on Ad Spend (ROAS) optimization</h2>
<p dir="auto">Not all conversions are equally valuable. There are many advertisers who sell a wide variety of items. Imagine a marketplace where some conversions generate $1 in profit, and other conversions generate $1000 in profit. Such an advertiser does not want to maximize the total number of conversions, they want to maximize their total profit. To this end, it’s desirable to try to estimate the conversion value given a conversion.</p>
<p dir="auto">We can combine all three predictions to estimate the conversion value given an impression</p>
<p dir="auto">E(conversion-value | impression) = E(conversion-value | conversion) * P(conversion | click) * P(click | impression)</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-multiple-targets-optimization-visits-registrations-sales-etc" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#multiple-targets-optimization-visits-registrations-sales-etc"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Multiple targets optimization (visits, registrations, sales, etc.)</h2>
<p dir="auto">Advertisers may want to track and attribute multiple natures of "conversions". Indeed many advertiser don't only focus on sales but also on visits, leads, etc.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-audience-selling" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#audience-selling"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Audience Selling</h2>
<p dir="auto">Some actors on the internet are able to build custom audiences, revealing strong user intent.  A business model is to sell these audiences to advertisers/brands for targetting purposes.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-crm-targeting" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#crm-targeting"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>CRM Targeting</h2>
<p dir="auto">Relationship/CRM Marketing: a marketing strategy designed to foster customer loyalty, interaction, and long-term relationships. It is designed to develop or reinforce a strong bond with existing customers by continuing a dialogue with them that provides the customer with information that matches their needs, problems, or interests.</p>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-problems-faced-by-non-logged-in-publishers" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#problems-faced-by-non-logged-in-publishers"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Problems faced by non-logged in publishers</h1>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-serving-relevant-ads" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#serving-relevant-ads"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Serving relevant ads</h2>
<p dir="auto">For websites that do not require a user to log-in, comparatively little (or perhaps no) information is known about the person browsing. This makes it extremely challenging to show a relevant ad. In certain cases it may be possible to show “contextual ads” that are reflective of the surrounding content, but in other cases this might not be possible.</p>
<p dir="auto">Search engines are a very special case, where contextual ads make a lot of sense. The search term already indicates a strong interest in a specific topic. For many use-cases though, “contextual ads” will have exceptionally little contextual information to work with.</p>
<p dir="auto">Today, publishers rely on 3rd party ad networks to serve relevant ads. These ad networks use 3rd party cookies to connect the person viewing the publisher’s website to some other source of information they have (perhaps from a logged-in website).</p>
<p dir="auto">If publishers can no longer rely on 3rd party ad networks, or if those networks themselves are unable to connect the user identity to any other source of information, publishers will struggle to show relevant ads.</p>
<p dir="auto">Irrelevant ads generally perform poorly (people do not engage with them), which will lead to reduced publisher revenues.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-running-an-auction" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#running-an-auction"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Running an auction</h2>
<p dir="auto">As mentioned above, most publishers rely on multiple 3rd party ad networks to serve relevant ads. One important use-case worth considering is how a publisher is to decide which ad network should serve an ad for a given opportunity.</p>
<p dir="auto">Today, the industry is slowly converging on “real time bidding”. This is the optimal mechanism for ensuring fairness, equal access, and equitable treatment. In such a system, each ad network is asked to “bid” on an ad opportunity. The highest bidder wins, and is given the chance to show an ad. They must pay the amount they previously bid.</p>
<p dir="auto">Today, this type of “bidding” arrangement can either be done client-side, or server-side. Server-side has many advantages, including reduced latency and less risk of fraud. Server-side bidding requires some piece of Ad-Tech (which is responsible for conducting the auction) to request a “bid” from multiple ad servers. It must send them some kind of information about this ad opportunity so that they know how much to bid. Simply sending the contextual data (e.g. the URL of the page requesting the ad) is not enough to make a bid. It’s important to know more about the person who will see the ad, to understand what ad to serve, and how much to bid. Today this is accomplished with various approaches that are inconsistent with the Webkit / Chrome privacy models.</p>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-affiliate-marketing" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#affiliate-marketing"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Affiliate Marketing</h1>
<p dir="auto">A lot of useful content on the web only exists because Affiliate Marketing provides the financial basis to support its creation.</p>
<p dir="auto">Publisher websites provide “affiliate links” to merchant websites. If the person clicks through and eventually completes a purchase, the publisher receives a portion of the sale price.</p>
<p dir="auto">There are many similarities with display ads, but the main difference is the payment scheme. Instead of being paid per impression or per click, the publisher is only paid when there is a conversion.</p>
<p dir="auto">Returns complicate this significantly. If someone makes a purchase, but subsequently returns the item, the publisher should not be paid for that conversion. The challenge of reversing a payout for a reported conversion is not well solved for today.</p>
<p dir="auto">Another concern is fraud. Fraudsters may attempt to utilize “click flooding” / “click spamming” to take credit for conversions they played no part in driving. Malicious browser extensions are also a big threat here. They have the power to intercept traffic and thereby take credit for conversions they did not drive.</p>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-enablers-for-first-parties" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#enablers-for-first-parties"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Enablers for first parties</h1>
<p dir="auto">Section on use-cases which are not strictly advertising driven but will need consideration in terms of how they can be handled in the web-platform going forward as they are key enablers for publishers, advertiser as well as users.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-federated-single-sign-on" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#federated-single-sign-on"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Federated Single Sign-on</h2>
<p dir="auto">Across all the proposals already published and the viewpoints shared by the browsers (Privacy Models), it is quite clear that 1-st parties in general will need to build more direct/explicit consumer relations to be able to sustain advertising supported business models in the open web. Federated Sign-on as a means of scalable authorization / authentication is a key enabler to that. It servers both site owners, simplifying consumer onboarding, as well as the users in terms of ease of use, transparency, security etc.</p>
<p dir="auto">As noted in the WebID Proposal, identity federation has been standardized outside the web platform largely by just using basic primitives (re-directs/cookies). Anticipating changed behavior/constrained use of them, there is a need for a more explicit integration while still being compatible with the existing federation protocols.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-view-through-site-personalization" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#view-through-site-personalization"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>View-through Site Personalization</h2>
<p dir="auto">When a site/brand wants to customize the content of their web pages based off of the user having seen a particular ad or opened a particular email.  This is often about a consistent, more straight-forward user experience - so if a brand shows someone a particular product/sale, and then that user shows up at their site, the user doesn't have to dig around to find out what they're interested in.  This use case might be covered by the same methods as view-through attribution - but this particular use case does require it to be available in real-time.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-click-through-site-personalization" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#click-through-site-personalization"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Click-through Site Personalization</h2>
<p dir="auto">When someone clicks a link to a website, that URL might encode information that can be used to personalize the experience. It might be a link to a particular offer or product. It might be a link that is specific to a particular marketing campaign. It might be personalized to the person themself.</p>
<p dir="auto">One special call out relates to "Landing Page Personalization". In the case that the website is accessed by a click on an ad, the website owner may work with the Ad-Tech provider to customize the link based on data provided by the Ad-Tech provider, the website owner or both.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-on-site-sponsored-product" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#on-site-sponsored-product"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>On-site Sponsored Product</h2>
<p dir="auto">Another area of digital adverting is called sponsored products. Brands launch this type of campaigns in order to obtain preferential placements for their products on retailers' or big marketplaces' websites.
Contrary to the other use cases mentioned above, the entire process from printing to ad to the actual sales happens on the retailer's website (there is no redirecting outside of the retailer's domain).</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-search" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#search"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Search</h2>
<p dir="auto">Advertisers use services like Google Shopping to advertise their products directly in Search Engines' results.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-ad-safety" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#ad-safety"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Ad Safety</h2>
<p dir="auto">Publishers usually consider that some ads contain inappropriate imagery, promote inappropriate products or messages they don't want to be associated with.
Each publisher needs to be able to maintain a "block-list" of specific brands, categories of brands, or specific pieces of ad creative that a given publisher would not want to appear on their site.   Block lists need to be able to update quickly, and affect both contextual and interest-based ad placements.</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Publishers need the list of all of the redirecting domains of the ads that were printed on their real estate and access to the visual rendering of each ad, so that they can review this list from the perspective of "Ad Safety".</strong> This reporting is used to investigate reported misconducts and update the block-list.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-malvertising-protection" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#malvertising-protection"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Malvertising Protection</h2>
<p dir="auto">Some ads may contain (or link to) malware. Publishers need a mechanism to block malware from being served to their sites' users and to take appropriate action against the source of the malware.  In the event that a malvertising campaign is discovered, publishers require mechanisms to block affected ads from appearing on their sites.</p>
<p dir="auto">Publishers use third-party malvertising detection services to prevent malvertising from serving to their users.</p>
<p dir="auto">In the event that an ad server, DSP, or other service is compromised and may have served malware, the blocking needs to apply to bundles that may already have been cached.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-pausing-advertising" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#pausing-advertising"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Pausing Advertising</h2>
<p dir="auto">Marketers sometimes choose to rapidly pause their ads in all media after an adverse news event such as a product recall or  airplane crash. Publishers of any web property on which the marketer's ad might appear will need to apply the pause to any ad placement on their sites.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-advertisers-exclusion" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#advertisers-exclusion"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Advertisers exclusion</h2>
<p dir="auto">As a Publisher, get the ability to blacklist ads from a list of advertisers.</p>
<p dir="auto">E.g. As owner of mylocalnews.com, I don't want to have any ad from any other newspaper on my site.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-revenue-management" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#revenue-management"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Revenue management</h2>
<p dir="auto">As a Publisher, I want to:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Have a daily detailed and accurate reporting of advertising revenues on my properties.</li>
<li>Have the ability to investigate and understand variations in my advertising revenues.</li>
<li>Have the ability to reconcile and investigate discrepancies between the reporting I get on my ad revenues and the revenues that will actually come from advertisers or ad networks.</li>
</ul>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-support-directly-sold-ads" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#support-directly-sold-ads"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Support Directly Sold Ads</h2>
<p dir="auto">Publishers need to be able to fulfill directly sold ad placements. Many publishers often secure higher-revenue advertising based on the ability to deliver guaranteed impressions. Publishers need to balance short term optimization of revenue with longer-term strategic client relationships, which means serving lower priced ads ahead of higher priced ads in certain cases. Being able to control this without a time delay is critical to publishers meeting their contractual and strategic goals.  Publishers can currently make direct and real-time bidding (RTB) work together using a variety of techniques. For example the highest RTB bid should not always win. Publishers need the flexibility to be able to optimize their revenue and strategic goals by controlling which ads are delivered for given placements, which rely on configurable rules that compare direct sold ads, and indirect sold ads.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-floor-rates" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#floor-rates"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Floor Rates</h2>
<p dir="auto">Publishers need to set floor rates (a minimum rate below which an ad will not be shown, even if there is no ad at a higher rate) based on several criteria.</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">A publisher may not want an ad to serve at all, if it is below a minimum floor set for that page, section, or site.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">A publisher may not want an ad from a certain brand, vertical or campaign unless it is above a minimum floor set for that brand, vertical, or campaign.  For example, a publisher may set a "floor for automotive." Publishers choose to protect their direct sales business, by not allowing marketers to undercut their pricing by way of other channels.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-competitive-exclusions" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#competitive-exclusions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Competitive exclusions</h2>
<p dir="auto">Publishers need to honor contractual terms preventing competitors from appearing together. If the contextual system serves an ad for one brand in one slot on the page, the decision process in other ad slots needs to know not to serve direct competitor ads. The publisher needs to control which brands are considered competitors. (A pair of brands might be considered direct competitors in one publisher niche, but not another.)</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-weighted-bidding" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#weighted-bidding"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Weighted bidding</h2>
<p dir="auto">The bid price set by the marketer is not necessarily the price at which it should compete in the auction. Publishers need to apply their own weighted prices, not necessarily the bid price. The "price" of a given ad is assigned by the buyer, but that price may not be what the publisher gets paid. In this case the publisher needs to apply an adjustment for auction purposes. Adjustment must be applied by the publisher in a 1st-party context. (Related issue: <a href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/14" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/WICG/turtledove/issues/14/hovercard">Ad Pricing · Issue #14 · WICG/turtledove</a>) Some examples:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">VAST errors: If a given ad is known to have VAST errors 20% of the time (for example, does not serve) then it needs to have its effective bid price reduced by 20%, by the publisher.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Post-bid brand safety blocking: If a given buyer has brand-safety controls that prevent an ad from serving on a page, the publisher ultimately does not get paid. Publishers can currently adjust for this by reducing the effective bids for impressions from a given buyer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">Reporting discrepancies: For many reasons, buyer and seller reporting (and third parties) does not match, and publishers need to be able to reduce (or increase) the bid price based on those discrepancies to ensure the ads compete at a price that is equal to what the publisher actually gets paid.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-user-needs-1" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#user-needs-1"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>User needs</h1>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-why-am-i-seeing-this-ad" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#why-am-i-seeing-this-ad"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Why am I seeing this ad?</h2>
<p dir="auto">One user need is to be presented with an accurate explanation of why a particular ad was shown. This is especially important in use-cases like re-targeting when people want to understand how personal information is shared. When no explanation is provided, people may imagine innacurate theories as to why they are seeing a given ad.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-opt-out-of-an-advertiser-category-or-product" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#opt-out-of-an-advertiser-category-or-product"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Opt-out of an advertiser, category or product</h2>
<p dir="auto">One user need is the ability to opt-out of all ads from a specific business. This could be for any reason, but examples might include a dislike for that particular company / brand, a lack of relevance, excessively repetitive ads from that business in the past, a prior bad experience with that business, or offensive ad imagery.</p>
<p dir="auto">The compexity in serving this user need comes from the difficulty in recognizing which ads promote which businesses. A given business may run ads through many channels, through many different ad agencies, and might promote a variety of apps and websites. All of this makes it very difficult to successfully satisfy this user need.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-opt-out-of-a-marketing-service" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#opt-out-of-a-marketing-service"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Opt-out of a marketing service</h2>
<p dir="auto">As a user, upon request I want to easily be able to opt-out of ads provided by a specific marketing service.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-seeing-ads-relevant-to-me" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#seeing-ads-relevant-to-me"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Seeing ads relevant to me</h2>
<p dir="auto">As a user, I prefer to see ads that are relevant to me.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-smooth-user-experience" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#smooth-user-experience"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Smooth user experience</h2>
<p dir="auto">As a user, I do not want:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Ads to degrade my browsing experience, in term of navigation, e.g.: ads blocking access to content or slowing down page load.</li>
<li>Ads to be annoying, e.g.: get to many times ads for the same product, or ads for products I already bought.</li>
</ul>
</article>
  </div>

    </div>

  </readme-toc>

readabilityObject.title: web-advertising/support_for_advertising_use_cases.md at main · w3c/web-advertising
readabilityObject.content:
Advertising Use Cases

This document provides an overview of key advertising use cases that depend on cross-site data sharing.

This document is broken down into 4 main sections based on the needs of the various entities in the web advertising ecosystem:

  • Advertiser Needs
    • Basic Advertiser Needs
    • Specialized Advertiser Needs
  • Ad Network Needs
    • Core Ad Network Needs
    • Specialized Ad Network Needs
  • Publisher Needs
  • User Needs

Advertiser Needs

Basic Advertiser Needs

All advertising aims to drive an outcome. There are many types of desirable outcomes, and these outcomes differ along several key axes:

  1. Immediate vs delayed: signing up to be an Uber driver right now, vs. remembering to consider a Mercedes next time they're buying a car
  2. Actions vs. Attitudes: taking a specific action like dialing a lawyer's office vs. just remembering to "Think Different"
  3. Direct vs. Indirect: buying glasses directly from warbyparker.com, vs. buying Ray-Ban's from their local optician after seeing a Youtube ad

Outcomes that are immediate, direct actions are typically referred to as "conversions" and the type of advertising that prioritizes conversions is typically called "direct response advertising." Conversely, advertising that focuses on outcomes that involve a change in attitudes or involve actions that are delayed (and often indirect) is typically called "brand advertising."

(Please see the document on Advertising Outcomes in this repo for a list of more potential outcomes.)

Both types of advertising are prevalent on the internet, and many ad campaigns by larger advertisers include a blend of both types. Direct response advertising represents the majority of digital advertising, but in recent years spending on digital brand advertising has grown rapidly, particularly on premium publishers like the Washington Post and The New York Times. Some channels, like paid search, are dominated by direct response advertising. Others, like online video, are dominated by brand advertising.

When an advertiser spends money to run an ad campaign they want to answer three very basic questions about it:

  • How many people saw the ad? Was the ad visible, and was it shown to the people I intended to see it?
  • How successful was the campaign at driving the desired outcomes/conversions?
  • Are you confident that the ad impressions and ad conversions are from real, authentic people?

Although they sound like simple questions, in practice answering them well is a rather complex and difficult undertaking. The ads industry has endeavored to find good ways of answering these basic questions, and has developed a number of approaches to doing so, which is why there are more than 3 use-cases in this section.

  • Impression and Viewability Measurement
    • Viewability
    • Invalid Traffic
    • Third Party Verification
    • Audience Verification
  • Aggregate Conversion Measurement
    • Conversion Lift Measurement
    • Brand Lift Measurement
    • Click-through and View-through attribution heuristics
    • Multi-touch attribution
    • Cross Browser / Cross Device Measurement
  • Fraud Prevention
    • Conversion Fraud
    • Click-Flooding
    • Malicious Browser Extensions
    • Malicious Mobile Apps
    • Malicious browsers
  • Brand Safety
  • Billing Transparency
Use-case Chrome Safari Community Proposals
Impression and Viewability Measurement There should be no conflict with Chrome’s proposed “Privacy Model for the Web”. First parties should still be capable of measuring that the ads displayed on their own properties entered the viewport, that images and video were loaded, how much time they spent in the viewport, etc. None of this requires joining up user identity across multiple domains. The only possible complication that might arise would be with "blind rendering" as described in proposals like "TURTLEDOVE" and “PETREL”. Here, the publisher would have restricted access to the ad being rendered and we will have to discuss the feasibility of "viewability" measurement. There is a discussion on this GitHub issue. Similar answer as that for Chrome. This should not be in conflict with Webkit's Tracking Prevention Policy given the measurement is entirely within the scope of a single publisher website.
Audience Verification No support No support No Support
Conversion Lift Measurement A section of the Conversion Measurement with Aggregation proposal describes explicit support for view through conversions, which should be sufficient to support lift measurement using experiments on a first party site (e.g. when using a first-party identifier to decide which experiment branch a person is in). No support Facebook proposal for “Private Lift Measurement”
Brand Lift Measurement No support No support No support
Click-through attribution Proposal: “Click Through Conversion-Measurement Event-level API” Proposal: “Private Click Measurement API”
View-through attribution A section of the Conversion Measurement with Aggregation proposal describes explicit support for view through conversions. No support
Multi-touch attribution The Event-level API proposal covers last-click attribution. A section of the Conversion Measurement with Aggregation proposal describes support for some built-in multi-touch models, and acknowledges that measurement providers writing their own models would be good to support if technically feasible. No support Facebook proposal for “Privacy-Preserving Multi-Touch-Attribution and Cross-Publisher Lift Measurement”
Cross Browser / Cross Device Measurement No support No support Facebook proposal for “Cross Browser Anonymous Conversion Reporting”
Multi-Channel Attribution / Measurement No Support No Support Adobe proposal for "Privacy Preserving Multi-Channel Attribution"
Conversion Fraud A section of the Multi-Browser Aggregation Service Explainer describes using a service that includes an authentication mechanism. This use case is also being explored for the event level API in this GitHub Issue. Confirmation this is a use-case Safari cares about addressing. In the process of collaboratively designing a solution on this GitHub Issue. Facebook proposal for “Private Fraud Prevention”
Click Flooding No solutions yet for this problem. However, lift measurement could be a potential way of measuring this problem. This might be supported by the “Aggregate Reporting API”. No solutions yet for this problem. Facebook proposal for “Private Lift Measurement” a potential way of measuring this problem
Malicious Browser Extensions No solutions yet for this problem. No solutions yet for this problem.
Malicious Mobile Apps No solutions yet for this problem. No solutions yet for this problem.
Malicious Browsers No solutions yet for this problem. No solutions yet for this problem.
Brand Safety There should be no conflict with Chrome’s proposed “Privacy Model for the Web”. When an ad targets an interest group, it is served as a web package with all subresources included and the detail of which interest group won lets you trace down the problematic campaign. However, the ads that were printed less than k times (k being the reporting threshold) would still pose a threat as they would remain undetectable because not reported. Similar answer as that for Chrome. This should not be in conflict with Webkit's Tracking Prevention Policy given the measurement is entirely within the scope of a single publisher website.
Billing Transparency In TURTLEDOVE, the browser is the sole owner of billing information.

Specialized Advertiser Needs

These are use-cases that only apply to a (possibly large) subset of advertisers.

  • Targeting
    • Audience definition
    • Exclusion Targeting
    • Lookalike Targeting
    • Retargeting
    • Display and target environment
  • Frequency
    • Frequency Capping
    • Frequency Optimization
  • Businesses with Multiple Domains
  • Ads directing to large marketplaces
    • Collaborative ads
    • Dynamic Ads
    • Email Marketing
  • Real time spend management
  • Catalog management
    • Product availability management
    • Price management
    • Products promotion management
  • Creatives
    • Coupon Management
  • Product Recommendation
Use-case Chrome Safari Community Proposals
Audience definition
Exclusion Targeting Acknowledgement that this is a valuable use-case and a link to Facebook’s PETREL proposal on this GitHub Issue No support Facebook proposal for “Private Exclusion Targeting Rendered Exclusively Locally (PETREL)”
Lookalike Targeting Might be possible to achieve limited support by leveraging “Federated Learning of Cohorts (FLoC)”. Might require an extension to TURTLEDOVE offering a new way to create interest groups, which Chrome indicated support for in this issue. No support Facebook proposal for "Privacy Preserving Lookalike Audience Targeting"
Retargeting Proposal: "Two Uncorrelated Requests, Then Locally-Executed Decision On Victory (TURTLEDOVE)" No support
Display and target environment Supported in TURTLEDOVE thanks to the contextual request. Ability to use this together with interest group request limited by the JS complexity.
Frequency Capping / Frequency Optimization For ads served via TURTLEDOVE interest-group targeting, the proposal offers a way to handle frequency capping on-device. For other types of targeting, while it will not be possible to enforce a hard "frequency-cap" across multiple websites, it might be possible to calibrate a target average frequency model. See discussion about how to do this on the explainer for the Aggregate Reporting API. No support Adobe Proposal for "Frequency Capping and Frequency Optimization"
Businesses with Multiple Domains Proposal: "First Party Sets" Some discussion in this GitHub issue indicates weak support for at least the country-specific eTLD use-case, but various concerns with the current "First Party Sets" proposal.
Collaborative Ads / Dynamic Ads Some discussion in this GitHub issue. No solutions or even strong acknowledgement of the importance of this use-case yet. Some discussion in this GitHub issue. Good collaborative problem solving going on. No firm solution yet. Facebook proposal for “Conversion Filters”
Email Marketing unclear unclear
Real time spend management High latency in TURTLEDOVE as the javascript updates have unknown frequency, and reporting is delayed in the Aggregate Reporting API Supported as ads are not done in opaque iframe and bidding is not done remotely
Product availability management More details required.
Price management More details required.
Products promotion management More details required.
Creatives The creative building logic and material is all contained in the web bundle. Questions arise about the size of the web bundle. More details required.
Coupon Management Some discussion in this GitHub issue. No solutions or even strong acknowledgement of the importance of this use-case yet. Facebook proposal for "Conversion Filters".
Product Recommendation Some discussion in this GitHub issue. Possible solutions addressed in issues #31 and #36 Facebook proposal for "Conversion Filters". RTB House proposal for "Browser-side personalization". Nextroll Proposal for "Dynamic Creative Use Case"

Ad Network Needs

Core Ad Network Needs

These are core essentials ad networks need to deliver value to advertisers.

  • Training ML Models
    • Click Through Rate (CTR) Model: P(click | impression)
    • Conversion Rate (CVR) Model: P(conversion | click)
    • Post-view attribution: P(conversion | impression)
    • P(Display | Request)
    • Return on Ad Spend (ROAS) optimization
    • Multiple Targets optimization
Use-case Chrome Safari Community Proposals
P(click | impression) There is no conflict with Chrome’s proposed “Privacy Model for the Web”. Should be possible to use 1st party cookies to tie together multiple sessions from the same browser on the same website. isLoggedIn may potentially pose problems here for websites without login. Limited storage may make it hard to tie together multiple sessions from the same person.
P(conversion | click) This is a stated goal of Chrome’s “Click Through Conversion-Measurement Event-level API” Not possible to train an ML model.
Post-view attribution: P(conversion | impression) Not possible to train an ML model. However, It may be possible to use the "Aggregate Reporting API" to obtain average conversion value measurement for very coarse-grain buckets of people. This could be used to perform calibration at this coarse-grain bucketed level. Not possible to train an ML model.
P(Display | Request) No support. Not possible to train an ML model.
Return on Ad Spend (ROAS) optimization Not possible to train an ML model. However, It may be possible to use the “Aggregate Reporting API” to obtain average conversion value measurement for very coarse-grain buckets of people. This could be used to perform calibration at this coarse-grain bucketed level. Not possible to train an ML model.
Multiple Targets optimization No support Not possible to train an ML model.

Specialized Ad Network Needs

  • Audience Selling
  • CRM Targeting
Use-case Chrome Safari Community Proposals
Audience Selling Probably possible under "TURTLEDOVE" by defining interest groups usable by other parties. No support
CRM Targeting possible if done via interest groups under "TURTLEDOVE" No support

Publisher Needs

These use-cases are more focused on the publisher's perspective.

  • Problems faced by non-logged in publishers
    • Serving relevant ads
    • Running an auction
  • Affiliate Marketing
  • Enablers for first parties
    • Federated Single Sign-on
    • View-through Site Personalization
    • Click-through Site Personalization
  • On-site Sponsored Product
  • Search
  • Ad Safety
  • Malvertising Protection
  • Pausing Advertising
  • Advertisers exclusion
  • Revenue management
  • Support directly sold ads
  • Floor rates
  • Competitive exclusions
  • Weighted bidding
Use-case Chrome Safari Community Proposals
Serving relevant ads (non-logged in publishers) Proposal: “Federated Learning of Cohorts (FloC)”. No support
